field_edited_text.value:
60 Pararsco RiveEr CROSSING

operate a 100,000 pound seaplane, costing $1,500,000.00 with 100 passen-
gers aboard over built up areas where in making a turn a forced landing
would mean disaster.

“Present seaplanes require a 2000 foot take off distance as compared to
the proposed Consolidated 100 passenger long range flying boats which will
require 7000 feet for take offs. It is therefore obvious that planes of this
magnitude will have to confine their operations to the unobstructed areas
south of the present Airport. The following data gives the operating
specifications of the large seaplanes:

Seaplane
(1) Douglas DF
Takeoff. ... .. .............. .. 35 seconds (approx. 2000 ft.)
Rateof climb. .. ....... ... .. .. 600 ft. per minute.
Gross weight. . . .. b 3 @0 SR G R 28,500 pounds.
(2) Sikorsky S-42-B (Bermuda Clipper)
Takeoff............... e under 60 seconds (approx. 3500 ft.)
Rate of climb. .. ... ....... .. .. 800 ft. per minute.
Gross weight. .. ... ... .. ...... 42,000 pounds.
(3) Boeing 314 (largest seaplane)
Takeoff..................... .. 50 seconds (approx. 3200 ft.)
Rateof climb. . .............. .. 650 ft. per minute.
Gross weight . . ............. .. .. 82,500 pounds.
(4) Consolidated Long Range
Takeoff....................... 97 seconds (7000 ft.)
Rate of climb. . ... ... . ... .. .. 700 ft. per minute.
Gross weight. . ... ... ... .. .. 100,000 pounds.

“Present day seaplanes taking off from the area, which the Authority
proposes to patrol, the center of which is some 3} miles from the bridge,
can head in the direction of the bridge and will have reached an altitude
of 1000 feet above the bridge towers when passing over them. The law
requires that so far as practicable aircraft shall not be banked immediately
after take off until a minimum altitude of 500 feet has been attained.
Therefore, a seaplane taking off from the proposed area will have reached
